case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy presents to the c   linic for evaluation of a progressively worsening nail dystrophy that began a few months ago. The patient’s mother denies a    family hi   story of skin diseases and reports th at her son has no    history of medical problems. On physical  examination, all of the boy’s fingernails and toenails show hyperkeratosis, longitudinal    ridging, loss of luster, and roughness. His h air, skin, and oral mucosa are unremarkable. Nail biopsy reveals spongiotic changes and exocytosis of inf   lamm  atory cells into the nail epithelia. The resul   ts of a fungal culture are negative.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My fingernails and toenails have become very rough, have lost their shine, and have deep lines running along them. They've also become thickened.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for a few months now.
Do you have any other skin symptoms, such as rashes, dry skin, or skin thickening anywhere else on your body?
No, my hair, skin, and the inside of my mouth all look normal.
Do you have any joint pain, stiffness, or muscle weakness?
No, I don't have any joint pain, stiffness, or muscle weakness.
Do you have any history of psoriasis or any other skin-related issues in yourself or in your family?
No, there is no history of skin diseases in my family, and I have not had any previous medical problems.
Have you been exposed to any chemicals or do you work in an environment that might expose you to irritants?
No, I have not been exposed to any chemicals or environments that might expose me to irritants.
Are you currently taking any medications, or have you recently started a new medication?
No, I am not taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Onychogryphosis.
